You've said that is a matter for the Fair Work Commission. I need to understand: when we say 'different states and territories', can you confirm that coast to coast is ruled out? I ask that because I do have some people listening in who have asked me specifically to get that guarantee from you again.
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:16): I've already answered that.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:16): I just need to clarify that, because one minute it's the Fair Work Commission and the next you're able to provide an answer. Employers in different states and territories—Fair Work Commission. I accept that, but I need to understand: in relation to coast to coast, does that capture also the Fair Work Commission or have we formally ruled that out? The west coast to the east coast—if we've formally ruled that out, that's actually a good thing. I will give you that. That is actually a good thing. I just need that clarification.
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:17): I refer to my earlier answers.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:17): Going to the public interest test now, can you take me through what the public interest test actually is?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:17): Senator Cash, are you talking about the single-interest bargaining stream here? Yes. I presume you're asking in relation to what will be section 249(3), which talks about common interest? Yes. It says that authorisation must not be contrary to the public interest. Again, I think these are commonsense decisions for the Fair Work Commission to make. I don't think there's been any further definition provided of that. Of course, as would be the case with any other statute, the commission will take into account the objects of the act, but also I've been reminded that, on page 187, under section 107(4), the revised explanatory memorandum states:
For example, when considering whether it would be contrary to the public interest to make the authorisation, the FWC—
the Fair Work Commission—
would have regard to the objects of the FW Act—
as I just mentioned—

… such as whether making the variation will promote productivity and economic growth while being fair to working Australians, and the objects of Part 2-4 … such as whether approving the variation promotes collective bargaining in good faith, particularly at the enterprise level.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:19): Again, the Fair Work Commission obviously has a very large role there. Can I just go back to guaranteeing that the public interest test will prevent multi-employer strikes that shut down an entire port, based on what you've just outlined to the committee?

Senator WAT
T (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:19): Sorry, Senator Cash; I was just a bit distracted there. Would you mind repeating that one?

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:20): In terms of the public interest test, you've now put on the record what some of the considerations are, but you also did say that it would be left to the Fair Work Commission, when I first asked what the public interest is. I just need to understand: can you guarantee that the public interest test—you've elaborated on it, and this is actually a very serious question I've been asked by an industry—will prevent multiemployer strikes that shut down an entire port?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:20): As I've said, Senator Cash, I'm not going to be getting into hypothetical situations, but I can remind you that, under the current legislation, which we've inherited from your government, we very nearly had an industry-wide lock-out of ports, effectively, by Svitzer, until the Fair Work Commission intervened. So the very scare campaign that you seek to run about what may happen actually nearly occurred under your own legislation.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:21): How many conciliation conferences occurred in the Svitzer matter?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:21): As you'd be aware, Senator Cash, conciliation conferences are usually undertaken in private, so that's really a question that only the parties could answer—and the commission.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:22): How many instances of industrial action occurred since the Svitzer enterprise agreement came to an end in 2019 that were undertaken by employees and unions?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:22): I think it's a matter of public record that there were multiple occasions of industrial action taken by employees of Svitzer, and I'm aware, again from public debate, that that was in response to what they considered to be an unreasonably unwilling approach from Svitzer to bargain. The commission has recently effectively ordered Svitzer to get back to the bargaining table, which is a good thing.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:23): Can you confirm that there were more than 250 instances of protected industrial action by the Maritime Union of Australia after 20 October 2022?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:23): Well, I've already said that there were multiple occasions of industrial action. That's after Svitzer attempted to lock out its entire workforce and shut down every port in Australia.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (20:24): I have a question for the minister about the role of the Fair Work Commission with its new objects in relation to gender equality and job security. In particular, can you give us an indication about whether you see it as part of its role to respond to a recommendation like this, which was made by the Select Committee on Work and Care in its interim report, that is to develop an analysis of care work classifications and wage structures to systematically address underpayments and lift wages in the care sector? Such an analysis could consider the variability and value of work across the care sector and establish the interrelationships across different care types, recognising and revaluing the value of care work.

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:25): That is an important object for us in this bill. Increased pay for those feminised industries has been a significant focus, and that will be something that we think will be addressed. We've obviously had a significant focus on early childhood education and care, and we think that this bill will help secure better pay for those workers in particular, so with a real focus on those feminised industries. There have been some examples that we have used to highlight why this legislation will be beneficial. We talked about Jane, who's been an early childhood educator for 40 years. She works at the East Brunswick Kindergarten and Childcare Centre. She is incredibly passionate about her job, as many are in the early education space, but it's been a tough industry for her to dedicate her life to. That's because of the constant struggles with staffing, and the low wages have been a significant factor in this sector for a long period of time now. Jane and her staff, along with workers in 70 other centres in Victoria, benefit from being part of a multi-employer agreement. They've won wages 15 to 18 per cent above the award. Just as importantly, they've won things like more time for planning and professional development. At the end of the day that's what delivers the better quality care for children that they are providing the care for.

But the process that they have to go through to get there is currently drowning in red tape. It shouldn't be that hard. Directors in these centres are usually educators as well. They're not workplace professionals or HR professionals. We're removing the red tape so that people like Jane—and there would be thousands of Janes across the country—can do more of that essential work that they can do, but they can get the pay they deserve at the same time.

The other thing that is important when you consider this legislation is that the early education sector is an area where we have a real skill shortage at the moment. Obviously attracting people to those professions is going to be easier if the pay is more adequate and deserving of the work they do. So we think that this bill will be a significant part of our ability to deliver, to ensure that those feminised industries are getting the appropriate pay. Also it will help us to attract people to go and work in the industries at the same time. It does have a significant impact both on pay but also on attracting people to work in that area where there are significant skills shortages.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (20:28): Thank you for that answer. That's obviously really important and reassuring in terms of the skill crises that are across that care sector. As you say, there are many thousands of Janes. We've heard of many of them in the work of the Select Committee on Work and Care. Could you comment further, though, not just about the childcare classification structure, which is fairly truncated and doesn't really recognise the full gamut of skills that early childhood educators deploy, and how they relate to the similar skills in the disability sector and in the aged care sector? What we have is a plethora of job types that have never been properly revalued in relation to each other. We've got the aged care sector running ahead at a long overdue 15 per cent pay rise, but what would be the role, specifically of the panel, on care and community services? Would it be an appropriate role to consider the relativities across that really important and growing part of the economy and analyse what are appropriate relativities in the care economy broadly?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:30): Thanks, Senator B Pocock, for the question. We have set up two panels that will be responsible for looking at the specific areas that you mentioned. One is with regard to pay equity, and the other is with regard to the care and community sector. So I do note the work that that committee did, and I think that it was quite a decent effort to do that committee in the short time frame that you did. Not all Senate committees work as efficiently as that one, and that's a particularly good effort for someone who is relatively new to the Senate at the same time. We see that as being a significant part of what we do. Obviously we went to the election saying that we want people to get a wage increase. We know that people have been struggling, but it again comes back to that point I made before about attracting people to these industries. It is really tough while the wages are low.

I spend a significant amount of my time in regional Australia and particularly regional Queensland, and I know how hard it is to attract people to work in some of these industries—whether it be aged care, whether it be providing services through the NDIS. There's not the market in a lot of these places that there is in the capital cities, so it's about attracting people to this workforce and ensuring they've got the training that they need to work in this area but also ensuring that they're getting paid adequately so that (1) we can attract people, so that they do see a career for themselves in this industry, but (2) once we do attract them, they become long-term employees. So it is something that we think is dealt with as part of this bill, and it's something that this government is absolutely passionate about delivering on, because (1) we want to see people paid better, but (2) we understand how important these community services are, whether it be in the NDIS, whether it be in aged care or whether it be in other parts of the care economy. We know how important those workers are to the community, and we think that they will greatly benefit from the parts of this bill that apply.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (20:32): Thank you for that answer. I want to ask a couple of questions about the minimum wage. One of the new objects of the act is to improve gender equality, and one of the fastest ways to do that is to lift the minimum wage. I wonder whether the government has considered any innovations or changes in relation to the minimum wage, and I just foreshadow we are going move an amendment to the bill, mirroring a development in many other countries, which is to lift the minimum wage to reach 60 per cent of median earnings. It's a quick route to narrowing gender pay equity, and it links the minimum wage to the average shift in wages across the country so that it will narrow inequality more broadly. I'm just wondering: did the government consider the kinds of things we are seeing across Europe now, where they have adopted a European directive around lifting the minimum wage to 60 per cent of median earnings?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:34): Again, thanks to Senator B Pocock for the question. It is an important issue you raise, and it is something that was also a discussion point at the Jobs and Skills Summit, where I think you might have been a participant at the same time. What we committed to doing at the Jobs and Skills Summit was a review into the living wage, and our commitment was to initiate a detailed consultation and research process on the concept of a living wage, reporting back in late 2023. That is something that we are still committed to. Obviously it is a significant issue, and I think that our commitment to gender equity that runs at the same time is important, and I think that, for the government, the fundamental premise of this bill is that it's designed to lift wages for Australian workers, particularly those who are our lowest paid workers.

We feel as though we have taken action around the commitments that we made in the lead-up to and during the election campaign and that we have obviously been committed to subsequently, in that, as one of our first acts in government, we have supported an increase in the minimum wage. I think the Australian people know where we land on these things and I think that this legislation is an important commitment, but we also know and acknowledge that there is ongoing work, and it doesn't end with the hopeful passage of this legislation in the next day or so.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (20:35): Thanks for that answer. We'll of course be watching that process unfold with great interest. I wonder if you could also give me a response, Minister, to another issue that we plan to raise in amending this bill, and that's in relation to requesting flexibility. The UK industrial law has for some time had a right to request flexibility, beginning with just parents and families. You could request flexibility in the UK if you had family responsibilities, but they've reviewed the way that law was working and have now moved to expand the right to request flexibility so that it's available to all workers. You don't have to be looking after a child. You may have a friend you want to care for. You may have a range of other reasons that make you seek flexibility. I wonder whether the government had considered learning from or building on the lessons of other countries and widening eligibility. The great value of it, in particular for men, is that it removes the stigma of putting your hand up and asking for flexibility, and that has a lot of dividends on the home front, in terms of redistributing care and domestic work.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:37): I thank Senator Chisholm for relieving me there for a little bit. Senator Pocock, we certainly support the intentions of what you're saying here, and I think you are proposing to move an amendment along these lines as well. As we've said, promoting gender equality is at the heart of our bill, and that's why gender equality will be included as an object of the Fair Work Act. Our bill also extends the right to request flexible work to pregnant employees, which does not exist under the current Fair Work Act. Our bill gives employees somewhere to go if their boss says no to their request. We do recognise, though, that it's important to balance the need for an employer to run their business with enhancing the rights for those employees who do rely on flexible work arrangements, and we feel that, at the current time, where we've landed on this point is the right place to land.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (20:38): You will know, Minister, that I'm an enthusiast for the backing up of the right to request flexibility, and I really appreciate that direction in the bill. Of course, we've talked a lot about that. I want to ask you about unpaid parental leave and the fact that, if the bill proceeds and the right enforcement is introduced in relation to requesting flexibility, the remaining national employment standard which won't have back-up will be the requesting of an extension of unpaid parental leave, and we will be moving an amendment in that direction also. I wonder if you want to foreshadow your response to that: is it time to make sure that all of the 11 national employment standards have back-up without leaving without a proper enforcement mechanism the one or two that are of particular relevance to women?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:38): Thanks, Senator Pocock. The government will be supporting that amendment. As you say, it includes a procedure for dealing with disputes arising from a request to extend an unpaid parental leave period modelled on the dispute resolution procedure for requests for flexible working arrangements. As you would no doubt be aware, Senator Pocock, there are only two entitlements in the National Employment Standards that are currently unenforceable: the right to request a flexible working arrangement and the right to request an extension of unpaid parental leave—and these entitlements are predominantly used by women. Our bill was already providing dispute resolution for one of those entitlements, being flexible work. We support this amendment to also provide dispute resolution for the right to request unpaid parental leave as well.
Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (20:40): That's great news. Thank you very much for that answer.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:40): Just building on the line of questioning that Senator Pocock has raised, Senator Watt, you weren't here when questions were being put to Senator Chisholm, but the government has said on numerous occasions that this legislation is all about getting wages moving and ensuring that Australians get a pay rise. Senator Chisholm did confirm that. In fact, in the overview of the bill, in the explanatory memorandum, it states the bill would amend the Fair Work Act 2009 and related legislation to get wages moving, boost job security, tackle gender inequity and restore fairness and integrity to fair work institutions.

So just building on the comments that Senator Chisholm made, in response to a line of questioning from Senator Pocock on the increase in wages that this bill will result in, he said, 'the Australian people know where we land on these things'. Could I ask you to elaborate a little further? When does the government expect wages to start increasing as a result of the legislation?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:41): Of course I'm not going to give a precise date on which we can expect to see wages get moving in this country, but what I can say is that obviously there are a range of agreements that already exist between employees and employers, and those agreements will have to see their course before workers in those particular businesses may see some benefit from this legislation. There are also grace periods provided through the legislation around the bargaining process.

What I can say is that if we leave the workplace relations laws in the way they currently are, without amendment, I can guarantee you we will get exactly the same result as we have seen for the last 10 years, which is stagnant wages and low productivity. It's in no one's interests to continue that. It seems that the coalition are the only group who think that that is a satisfactory way to go. I guess that's because they think that low wages are a deliberate design feature of their economy. But I can guarantee you that if we do nothing to change the system we will get the same result. That's why we are confident, again based on international evidence, that some of the changes that we're proposing here will deliver better wage outcomes and better productivity for employers. That's what underpins our commitment to making these changes.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:42): So we don't have a precise date, but you do say, as I said, in the explanatory memorandum: 'The bill would amend the Fair Work Act 2009 and related legislation to get wages moving.' Could you take us through what modelling was undertaken in relation to being able to make that statement in the explanatory memorandum.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:43): I'm having a sense of deja vu, Senator Cash, because I feel that you asked me that question at estimates. I guess I'll give you the same answer that I gave you at estimates, which is that there is no modelling on that point, but there is a very extensive body of international evidence that demonstrates that the kind of bargaining system that we are proposing in these laws delivers better wage outcomes for workers, better productivity for employers and, by virtue of that, a good return for the economy. So I feel very confident pursuing these laws on the basis of that international evidence.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:44): So you have confirmed that no modelling was undertaken in relation to the part of the explanatory memorandum that states, 'The bill would amend the Fair Work Act and related legislation to get wages moving.' We don't have a precise date or time frame in relation to when the government expects wages to start moving. Can you at least advise by how much you expect wages to start moving as a result of this legislation, given it clearly states in the explanatory memorandum 'to get wages moving'?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:45): Again, I think I answered this question at estimates, Senator Cash, but there's no-one in the country that could give a categorical answer on that, because of course every agreement that is struck is different. There will be some agreements that are struck under this legislation that provide for higher pay rises than others. There will be some agreements that are struck that provide for a range of different conditions, some better than others. That's how the system works. But what I can tell you is that things like inserting job security and gender equality as objects of the Fair Work Act will provide for a fairer system of work and pay rises. Things like banning job ads that pay less than the minimum wage will help lift wages. Things like sunsetting the zombie agreements that we still see in place that arose under your government's Work Choices legislation will help get wages moving again. So there are any number of actions being taken through this legislation which will get wages moving again, and that's something that the Australian people voted for at the last election.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:46): How many Australians will see their wages increase as a result of this legislation?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:46): Again, you wouldn't expect me to be able to provide that kind of answer, and that's why you've asked the question. It is interesting, though, that having spent weeks and months running around the country scaring employers and perhaps some employees about the risk of a wages breakout, we now have a series of questions from the opposition which seem to imply that workers won't receive a pay rise. So I guess the opposition at some point has got to make up its mind what the right scare campaign is. Is it going to be a continuation of scare campaigns that wages are going to be out of control, or are we going to pursue a different kind of scare campaign, which is that workers might not receive the wages that they think they might get? Perhaps some consistency from the opposition would be kind of helpful on this front.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:47): Organisations such as the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Industry Group have all said that this bill won't see an increase in wages, because fewer agreements will be made between the parties themselves, and terms and conditions will instead be determined by the Fair Work Commission by way of compulsory arbitration. This is because it will be virtually impossible for multiple employers to come to a common position and then agree with multiple unions—that is to say, the more parties involved, the less likely they will agree—increasing the risk that the matter will be decided by compulsory arbitration. We've heard tonight there's a lot being decided by the commission: 'We'll leave to it the Fair Work Commission. That's a decision for the Fair Work Commission. The Fair Work Commission will make that decision.' If more and more agreements are decided by the commission via compulsory arbitration and fewer agreements are reached between the parties themselves, despite the fact that we actually began with quotes from the minister in relation to the primacy of enterprise-level agreements, will the government concede that the provisions are not operating as intended?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:48): Thanks, Senator Cash. As you would know, the way the legislation is drafted provides for arbitration as a last resort, so I don't think that it's reasonable to assume that the majority of negotiations are going to result in arbitration. As I said earlier in this debate and as Minister Burke has said repeatedly, we want to see a system where employers and employees reach agreement, and there are multiple streams being provided for that to occur. It's our intention to drive up the level of agreements, and let's not forget that, generally speaking, workers who are covered by enterprise agreements end up with better pay rises, better conditions and better pay in general than those on the award. So it'll be a good thing if we can see more agreements struck, because that means that more workers will get pay rises. They'll have money to put into the local economy—and you know what? Employers will get better productivity out of it as well.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:49): I go back to the questions that we were asking in relation to, in particular, multi-employer agreements in the single-interest stream and the public interest test. I know that you had to step out, Senator Chisholm came in and we undertook a different line of questioning. Can you guarantee that the public interest test will prevent targeted efforts to pressure an employer by coordinating industrial action against its suppliers or customers who are also part of the same multi-employer agreement?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:50): As I said earlier in the night, our legislation actually imposes additional safeguards against the taking of unjustified industrial action. Conciliation needs to occur. There's the arbitration for intractable disputes. So any suggestion that this is going to lead to industrial mayhem and strikes of the kind that you're talking about is merely designed to scare people about things that are not provided for by this legislation.

Senator ROBERTS (Queensland) (20:51): Minister, you look like you need a break, so I will give you a break from your legal jousting and setting up definitions of terms for the future. In proposing this bill, the government says the bill aims to secure jobs. My amendment on sheet 1768 goes to the heart of ensuring job security and protecting workers' rights. To ensure job security, my amendment on sheet 1768 ensures that unjustified vaccine discrimination is stamped out in employment. The original bill inserts breastfeeding, intersex status and gender identity as attributes that the Fair Work Act protects from discrimination. This amendment copies that approach and simply adds COVID-19 vaccination status as an attribute protected from discrimination. The protection is still subject to the limits imposed on the other discrimination grounds in the Fair Work Act. An employer will not be in breach of the antidiscrimination grounds where the employer can prove, as they should have to, that it is a genuine and reasonable requirement of the position. This amendment is reasonable in its approach. It is not radical, because it uses and simply extends the existing mechanisms in the Fair Work Act.

We've long known that COVID vaccines do not stop transmission. Before this came apparent, however, getting vaccinated to 'protect others' was the justification many businesses used to roll out vaccine mandates. As a condition of keeping their job, many employees were coerced and still are being coerced into receiving COVID injections and boosters they do not want. The vaccine mandates cannot be justified, given the fact that vaccines do not guarantee protection from transmission.

The New South Wales Personal Injury Commission agrees with this view, with workers compensation being awarded for psychological distress stemming from mandates in the determination of Dawking and the Secretary of the Department of Education, handed down on 3 November. Sometimes the wheels of justice turn slowly, yet we are happy that judicial bodies are taking up this self-evident position that broad vaccine mandates cannot be justified.

Despite this, mandates are still in effect across much of the private sector. It's clear that further legislative action must be taken. Businesses are simply ignoring the evidence against unjustified vaccine mandates. A clear message needs to be sent that unreasonable directions that infringe on workers' rights have no place in Australian workplaces.

Often mandates do not even account for Australians that have accepted medical contra-indications to vaccination. The Australian newspaper reports that Qantas sacked a pilot for failing to comply with a vaccination mandate while he was off work in a serious health condition: being treated for bowel cancer. Separately, I've met a Qantas employee who, after being injected with the first COVID injection, was rushed to hospital with severe disability—possibly life-threatening—due to the COVID injection. After hospital care and partial recovery, he returned to work, where Qantas insisted he get the second injection. He contested it and is on a vastly reduced pay on workers' compensation. He fears his career with Qantas is finished. How can this be in this country?

This amendment seeks to reinforce workers' rights to refuse a workplace direction where it is not a reasonable and justified requirement of the job. It leaves no doubt for employees and employers that vaccine mandates must not be in place unless there is a reasonable and justifiable need for them. Minister, given that businesses continue to ignore workers' rights in this area, will the government support this amendment to reinforce the decisions of the Fair Work Commission and codify protections for workers against unreasonable workplace directions?

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Sterle ): Before I call the minister, I just need some assistance from the chamber here. We've managed to jump a number of amendments to get to yours on sheet 1768. I have a question before the chamber to deal with government amendments 1 to 68 on PV124.
Senator ROBERTS (Queensland) (20:55): I'm asking a question. I'm not moving my amendment.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Help me out, Senator Roberts. I know we're in for a long haul. You have to be relevant to the amendments I've got in front of me at the moment. So how can you make your questions relevant while I'm still trying to deal with government amendments on PV124?

Senator ROBERTS (Queensland) (20:56): It goes to the heart of the bill, which is where the current discussion has been going, into the security and the pay rates, the two justifications that the government is making for this legislation, supposedly. It goes to that job security.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Senator Roberts, I don't need any help, thank you very much anyway. If I do, I will call upon the Clerk. I will seek guidance from the Clerk, because I am just a little bit confused at the moment. Maybe it's the late hour. I will be back to you in a second. Senator Roberts, you and I are mates, but I'm going to stretch the friendship here and test it. You have to be relevant to the question—the government amendments in front of me. I'm happy to put the government amendments and take the vote on it now. I'm not making this up, Senator Roberts. I'm surrounded by some very intelligent, helpful people up here. I will put the question.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:57): I have a lot more questions.
The TEMPORARY CHAIR: Senator Cash, I was just going to read this, and I didn't see you jump.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:57): Can I go back to the questions in relation to the multi-employer agreement in the single-interest stream. We were talking about the common interest. In terms of the common interest, can you guarantee that two mining companies won't be found to have a common interest just because they both undertake mining?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:58): Thanks, Senator Roberts, for giving me a break. As you suggested, maybe there will be a time later where we can answer your questions. Senator Cash, as I've said already, the requirements that would need to be met for different employers to be brought together under a multi-employer agreement through the single-interest bargaining stream, whether they be in the mining industry or any other industry, are that they have clearly identifiable common interests and that agreement must not be contrary to the public interest. We've already talked about the fact that there are different factors which may be relevant to the commission in determining whether the employers have a common interest. They include geographical location, the regulatory regime and the nature of the enterprises. So again, it is a matter for the commission to make a decision on any particular case.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:59): 'A matter for the commission'. Thank you very much. Is it enough that two employers are in the same area and pay under the same award?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (20:59): Before I answer that question I should have pointed out that, in addition to the common interest test, the case involving mining companies that you're talking about would, as with any other case, also have to demonstrate that the operations and business activities of the different employers are reasonably comparable as well as meeting the common interest test.

In answer to your question about different businesses paying on the basis of the same award, the bill provides that one of the matters that may be relevant to determine whether the employers have a common interest is the terms and conditions of employment in those enterprises. That is one factor that could be considered, but, again, it's ultimately a decision for the commission. As I say, there is nothing unusual in industrial relations legislation about leaving matters for the commission to use its discretion.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:00): I beg to differ; it actually is unusual, unless it is a deliberate attempt to centralise decision-making with the Fair Work Commission. Despite our original line of questioning, where I understood the government really still wanted the primacy to be agreements at an enterprise level, every single answer to date is a centralised answer.

Could a small trucking company—again in the single-interest stream; 21 and above, just so I don't get taken through the 20 and below again—have a common interest with a large rail company, or can you rule that one out?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:01): I'm not a commissioner. I'm not going to prejudge what the commission—
Opposition senators: Oh, really?

Senator WATT: No, really, I'm not a commissioner. This is a matter for the commission to exercise its jurisdiction. It sounds from the comments from the opposition that they don't have confidence in the commission which, frankly, surprises me, given recent appointments. The commission will give consideration to a number of factors, and they are clearly set out in the bill.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:02): Could a civil construction firm and a mining company have a common interest because they undertake some work at the same worksite?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:02): Civil construction is exempt from multi-enterprise bargaining under the bill, so I guess the answer to that question is no.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:02): Would a construction firm and a mining company have a common interest because they undertake some work at the same site?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:03): The amendments that we're moving to the bill provide that work in the civil construction sector is to be considered general building and construction work, which means that work in that sector would not be subject to multi-enterprise bargaining.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:03): What is the government's rationale, then, for excluding certain parts of the building and construction industry from parts of the new bargaining stream?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:03): Under the bill, the Fair Work Commission must not approve multi-enterprise agreements that cover employees in relation to general building and construction work. Multi-enterprise agreements are not necessary or appropriate for the general building and construction industry. The scope of the work that has been excluded has been carefully defined to ensure that the exclusion is appropriately limited. Following government amendments in the Senate, general building and construction work will include work in the civil construction industry. As with general building and construction work, multi-employer agreements with not necessary or appropriate for the civil construction industry.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:04): Again, can you take me through the government's rationale for undertaking this action?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:04): The construction industry is actually the heaviest user of the single-enterprise enterprise bargaining system at the moment. So that industry have demonstrated that they can make single-enterprise agreements. Employees and businesses in this sector already have the opportunity to engage in enterprise bargaining. So, on the basis of the experience of the industry being a heavy user of the single-enterprise bargaining system, the government's view is that there's no need to open up multi-employer bargaining for this industry.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:05): Can I confirm again, for the Hansard record, that the exclusion for general building work as defined means that workers in the construction industry will then not enjoy the same bargaining rights as workers in all other sectors in the event that they're not employed under an enterprise agreement?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:06): All I can do is repeat that multi-enterprise bargaining will not be available for work in the civil construction sector which is considered to be general building and construction work. As I say, the rationale for that is that that industry are extremely heavy users of single-enterprise bargaining, and we have seen no evidence to suggest that that should change.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:06): When you say 'the civil construction sector', is there anything not included? I haven't looked at the amendment properly yet. Have you excluded anything from that definition?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:07): There are a couple of forms of what people might regard as construction work that are exempted from the exemption so that they would be able to make use of multi-employer bargaining. You may not have heard me say at the outset, Senator Cash, that one of the amendments that we are moving, following the negotiations with Senator David Pocock, is that the asphalt industry is not considered to be general building and construction work. Also, there is an amendment which I didn't mention earlier, which is about work that is the construction, repair, maintenance or demolition of powerhouses or other structures that use eligible renewable energy sources to generate electricity. So businesses and employees in those two industries—renewables and asphalt—would be able to access multi-employer bargaining provided they met all the other relevant tests.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:08): Just to confirm: there are some exemptions from the exemptions, which means they're in, as you've just confirmed. Can you take me to what amendments they are so we can have a look at them and come back tomorrow with a further line of questioning?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:08): Sorry; was there a question in there?

Se
nator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:08): What are the sections that we can go and have a look at, please?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:08): It's item (61) on the amendment sheet. I got one detail wrong there. The amendment in relation to renewables is as a result of the discussions with Senator Pocock. The amendment in relation to asphalt is not. That's because I think any reasonable person would not consider that work in the asphalt industry amounts to general building and construction work.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:09): So the amendment that you're moving is slightly different to how the original bill was drafted? That is my understanding.
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:09): Yes. That would be fair to assume, because they're new amendments.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:09): Can I then confirm this, having not had the benefit of being able to properly analyse the amendments because they were literally tabled as we were in this debate?
Would this mean that, if your employee were employed in a construction business which installed air-conditioning ducts in commercial building and construction, they would fall under 'excluded work'?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:10): The original bill itself, in what would be clause 651B—which adds a new section 23B—actually sets out what is not considered to be general building and construction work. One of the examples given is:
… work in connection with the installation, major modernisation, servicing, repair or maintenance of lifts and escalators, or air-conditioning or ventilation.

So that work—in relation to installation, major modernisation, servicing, repair or maintenance of, I think you said, air conditioning or ventilation—is not considered to be general building and construction work and therefore could be the subject of multi-employer bargaining if the employers and employees chose to do so and if it passed the other tests.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:11): So you've just confirmed the answer is yes. Would this mean that, if your employee was employed in a construction business to install air-conditioning ducts in commercial building and construction, they fall under this excluded work clause? The answer is no—they're actually in. You also just said, though, that the employer and the employee can agree to enter into multi-employer bargaining. Are you saying that the employer in this particular circumstance cannot be compelled?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:11): I was talking colloquially and saying that, if all the usual tests were met—and I'm reminded that there is an association. The exact name of it I've forgotten, but it's essentially for air-conditioning and maintenance. Mr Scavera, I think his name is, has been in the media speaking on behalf of businesses involved in this industry and has said that he and his members are very much looking forward to taking part in—
An opposition senator interjecting—

Senator WATT: Well, that's nine employers. I didn't know that we were being selective about which employers we thought were the right ones and the wrong ones. His members are very enthusiastic about taking part in multi-employer bargaining, and the reason he gave was that he and his members were sick of seeing rogue operators in the industry trying to undercut people through a race to the bottom for wages. So good on Mr Scavera and his members for wanting to do the right thing by their workers and wanting to do the right thing by their members. We want to see more of it.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:12): Just going back to the government's rationale for excluding certain parts of the building and construction industry, one of the reasons—in fact, it would appear to be the prime reason—that the government has undertaken this exclusion is, as you said, that their use of enterprise agreements is very, very high. My understanding is, though, that the mining sector, particularly on the east coast, is also a significant user of single-enterprise agreements. Was the government approached in any way by any of the mining companies to also have an exclusion on the basis that they already have a higher proportion of enterprise agreements, consistent with the government's rationale for excluding certain parts of the building and construction industry?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:13): I think it's pretty clear that representatives of the mining industry did make representations. Again, I think it's been in the media that they're not particularly happy about potentially being part of multi-employer bargaining. But, if those particular companies had a history of reaching single-enterprise bargaining agreements, I don't see any reason why they'd change course.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:14): That doesn't actually answer the question. The rationale that you have provided in relation to the exclusion of certain parts of the building and construction industry is based on the high proportion of enterprise agreements. The mining industry would argue that they also have a high proportion of enterprise agreements. So again I ask you: why weren't they excluded?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:15): Again, I can't really add anything to what I've said. But if mining companies want to continue with their practice of single enterprise bargaining agreements and if their workforce are content to go down that path then I expect that will continue.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:15): In relation to the rationale of the high proportion of enterprise agreements utilised by the excluded parts of the building and construction industry, what was the government's threshold in determining that you would therefore exclude certain parts of the building and construction industry?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:15): It's like the discussion we were having about metrics before. I don't think anyone set a metric for what percentage of agreements in a particular sector needed to be met in order for them to take part or not take part in multi-employer agreements, just as there was no metric that needed to be met to determine whether something is in the same geographical location. These are matters of judgement, and our judgement was that the practice in the construction industry was well set; it didn't need multi-employer bargaining. If mining companies want to continue their practice of single enterprise bargaining and their workforce agrees, then I expect they'll continue with it.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:16): Both Rio Tinto and BHP, particularly in Western Australia, have spoken out against being included in relation to the multi-employer bargaining single-interest stream. Did the Premier of Western Australia provide any representations to the Albanese government on behalf of Rio Tinto and BHP?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:17): Not that I'm aware of.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:17): What safeguards in the bill would prevent a multi-employer agreement growing to cover a whole industry or most of an industry or even across multiple industries? Does the bill limit the number of businesses that can be part of an agreement?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:17): If your question is whether there's a numerical limit on the number of businesses that can be part of a multi-employer enterprise, the answer is no. Of course, each of those businesses would need to pass the relevant tests, but, no, there's no numerical limit.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:18): Reverting to the first part of my question: what safeguards in the bill would prevent a multi-employer agreement growing to cover a whole industry or most of an industry or even across multiple industries?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:18): Well, the safeguards, as you put it, are that each of the businesses who—if a business is to become part of a multi-employer agreement, then all those tests would need to be met. To take one example, around the geographical location, it's hard to imagine that the commission exercising its discretion would include every single business in every single industry in the entire country. I think there are adequate safeguards in there for businesses who are concerned about that, and the bottom line is that any such bargain would need to be considered to be in the public interest by the commission.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:19): That, ultimately, is a matter for the Fair Work Commission. And you haven't ruled out, or you said, 'Does the bill limit the number of businesses that can be part of an agreement, the answer is no.' Just in terms of going back to—

Senator WATT
( Queensland — Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management ) ( 21:19 ): Can I respond to that?
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:19): That was your evidence.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:19): My evidence was actually that, for businesses to be part of a multi-employer bargain, it may well be that there are a large number of businesses in one geographical location that are subject to the same regulatory regime, that have the same terms of conditions of employment in those enterprises and are reasonably comparable, and therefore meet the tests to be part of a multi-employer bargain. But to suggest that that will mean that every corner store in the country, of varying sizes, selling different products—pizza stores, retail stores, hamburger stores, whatever kinds of stores—are going to be part of the same multi-employer agreement, I think, is exaggerating, because it would ignore the various tests that are put in place in the legislation.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:21): Can I go back to, then: does the bill limit the number of businesses that can be part of an agreement in a numerical sense? Was your answer 'no'?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:21): Yes, my answer was no.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:21): If I could return to the rationale in relation to the carve out of civil construction from, I understand, all streams of multi-employer bargaining. The agreement that you have with Senator Pocock, is it to include a complete carve out?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:21): I'm sure I'll be corrected if I'm wrong. The bill that we introduced, prior to the negotiations with Senator Pocock being finalised, already, to use your words, 'carved out' commercial construction work, and that was defined to be 'general building and construction work' in the original bill. That, of course, had the various exemptions to the exemptions that we were talking about before. What's changed as a result of the negotiations with Senator Pocock is that there's an additional form of what might be regarded as construction work, being work to do with renewable energy, that is also now exempted from the exemption. Just to clarify, as a result of the negotiations with Senator Pocock, the category of work that was excluded from multi-employer bargaining was expanded from being commercial construction work to civil and construction commercial work, and, through the course of those negotiations, it was agreed that construction work in relation to renewable energy would not be part of the exemption, and therefore could be subject to multi-employer bargaining.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:24): I now turn to the competition effects of this bill. Did the department or the government consider the competition effects of the bill?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:24): I know this issue about the application of competition laws has come up a bit and, again, has been used by some to create concern in the broader community, but industrial laws for some time now have been exempted from competition laws, so I don't think that the concerns that have been raised in this regard are valid.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:25): So industrial laws as they stand today under the unamended Fair Work Act—yes, you are right—are exempt from competition law. The bill that we are currently debating has some of the most fundamental changes to the industrial relations system that this parliament has seen in decades. You are opening up a new stream of multi-employer bargaining. In relation to the common interest test, the public interest test and the comparability test, you have advised the committee—it is on record for statutory interpretation purposes—that 'that will be left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission'. You have refused to rule out scenario after scenario after scenario: employers in different states and territories, employers across different industries, big businesses and small businesses, marginal businesses and profitable industries. I have asked you directly: does the bill limit the number of businesses that can be part of an agreement? The answer was no. So, when this bill passes, we will be talking about a fundamentally different state of affairs. And you are right: the impacts on competition have been raised time and time again in the incredibly short time that employers and employees across this country have had in relation to understanding the impact of this legislation. So, given that you admit that this issue has been raised—it hasn't been raised in relation to the current regime; it has been raised in relation to the fundamental changes that are now occurring—did the department consider competition effects of this bill? If not, why not?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:27): Yes, the department did consider this in drafting this legislation. What it also considered was the longstanding exemption of industrial relations laws as they relate to terms and conditions of employment from competition laws. In fact, the former commissioner of the ACCC Rod Sims has only today made the public statements that workplace relations laws, particularly in relation to the terms and conditions of employment, have been exempt from competition laws since 1965 for good social policy reasons. Nothing has changed as a result of this legislation.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:28): Was the bill run through Treasury to ensure that, when the changes are made into law, it will not create problems with the Competition and Consumer Act or other adverse consequences?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:28): Treasury, along with a range of other departments within the federal government, was consulted about the drafting of the bill. It's probably best to leave it at that.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:28): They were consulted. Were they specifically consulted in relation to the potential impact on the Competition and Consumer Act or other adverse consequences?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:29): They were consulted on the entire bill.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:29): In relation to the Competition and Consumer Act and the competition effects of the bill, what was Treasury's response?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:29): Senator Cash, you know from being a minister that you wouldn't, in this sort of debate, provide information about advice that one department has provided to another, and I don't propose to do so, either.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:29): Then without providing me the advice, were Treasury asked specifically in relation to the impact on competition and whether or not problems would be created within the Competition and Consumer Act—based on the fact that you have stated that this has been raised with the government?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:30): Again, Treasury was consulted about the entire act. Every provision in it was put to Treasury for their views, and they provided the feedback that they provided. What we're trying to get to in this country is a workplace relations system where we see competition among businesses on innovation, on the quality of their product or on the quality of the service that they offer to their customers, not competition based on undercutting each other's wages. That's what we're trying to achieve here. I'm trying to find the relevant section of the Competition and Consumer Act as well. The Competition and Consumer Act 2010 provides an exemption from the application of competition law in determining whether certain anti-competitive behaviour has occurred. The act actually says:
… regard shall not be had:
(a) to any act done, or concerted practice, to the extent that it relates to the remuneration, conditions of employment, hours of work or working conditions of employees …

Any act undertaken in accordance with any law, such as this law, which relates to, for instance, the remuneration, condition of employment, hours of work or working condition of employees is exempt from competition law under the very act that sets out the competition law of Australia, so any attempts that are being made to wind up employers that they might be subject to action from the ACCC are completely wrong and yet another false, baseless scare campaign from the coalition.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:32): Could you take me through the consultation that you had with the ACCC in relation to the competition effects of the bill?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:32): The ACCC, as you would recall, falls within the Treasury portfolio. The Treasury portfolio was consulted through the drafting of the bill. Again, we've had just today the former chair of the ACCC, Mr Sims, make the point that workplace relations laws and matters to do with the terms and conditions of employment are exempt from competition law, and it was there in black and white in section 51(2). Yes, the Treasury was consulted. ACCC falls within it. But it's pretty crystal clear in the law that there's nothing to be concerned about.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:33): Again, I'm not raising these concerns; businesses across Australia are raising the concerns, and they're not raising concerns in relation to the regime as it currently stands. They understand the regime as it currently stands. They are raising concerns in relation to the potential impact of multiemployer bargaining and the fact that competitors may well be compelled to bargain together. One of the purposes of the bill is to allow protected industrial action to occur across multiple employers at once. Can you just confirm that, where a single enterprise agreement expires and bargaining does not commence, that particular employer could be compelled to bargain under this act?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:34): Sorry, Senator Cash; could you just repeat the last part of the question?

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:34): If you currently have a single enterprise agreement and it is in force, I understand you are excluded; however, when that agreement comes to an end, if you do not recommence bargaining you could actually be compelled under this particular bill.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:34): You could be compelled to be part of a multi-employer bargain? Well, again, I know it suits the narrative to talk about businesses being compelled to be part of multi-employer bargains, but, as we've been talking about over the course of the night, a business might actually choose to be part of a multi-employer bargain. It does happen. There are businesses who want to do this. Mr Scavera, who I was referring to before, and his air-conditioning and ventilation businesses want to be part of this so that they can stop a race to the bottom on wages. But, even for those businesses who don't want to be part of it, first of all the majority of their workforce has to vote in favour of it and then they have to satisfy all of those common-interest and reasonably-comparable-business tests.

In relation to the competition matters and the concerns that you say businesses are raising, you've had many opportunities over the last few months, Senator Cash, when I and others have responded to your questions and given you the facts of the situation, to go out there and provide those facts to those businesses. But, for reasons of your own, you haven't done so, and you keep coming back asking the same questions and fuelling the scare campaigns that businesses, unfortunately, are on the other end of. I'd encourage you and your colleagues to actually pass on the facts that you have been repeatedly told rather than continuing to fuel scare campaigns on the basis of incorrect information that you've been repeatedly told is incorrect.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:36): What opportunity exists for an employer to exit the cooperative stream in the event that the collegiate negotiations they've entered into voluntarily move towards an arrangement that would make that employer's business unviable, resulting in probable business destruction and associated job loss? Additionally, how will these laws prohibit business conversations that would otherwise contravene Australian competition laws with respect to collusion?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:37): Well, I've obviously dealt with the collusion point by saying that there is no risk of anticompetitive conduct action being taken. In relation to the first point, as you say, the cooperative stream is available for businesses and employees who want to be part of a cooperative agreement, usually signing up to an agreement that other businesses would be part of as well. There is provision within the bill for businesses to withdraw from cooperative stream agreements if they have the agreement of the relevant union. Of course, if that isn't the case then, as is the case for many other agreements, that agreement that has been signed up to would expire at its expiry date.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:38): Again in relation to the common interest, I had asked you if you could confirm that, to satisfy the common interest test, all three factors do not need to be satisfied, and you said, 'No, they don't.' So can I just confirm, then, that there is nothing in the legislation that makes the Fair Work Commission consider any other factor—for example, it could determine that there is a geographical common interest and then move straight to the comparability test? Can you confirm that is true?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:39): I think the more important point here, Senator Cash, is that, to become part of a common interest or to be considered a common interest employer and therefore be part of a single-interest agreement, what is required by the act is that employers have clearly identifiable common interests and that it is not contrary to the public interest for the employer to join the agreement.

Those are the requirements. The remaining details, such as the geographical location, the regulatory regime and the nature of the enterprises are simply examples of what the commission may consider in determining whether employers have a clearly identifiable common interests. So more than anything, what would need to be demonstrated is that a particular employer has clearly identifiable common interests with the other employers and that it's not contrary to the public interest for them to be joined. Of course, in addition there's now a new reasonably comparable test as well.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:40): Can I just confirm 'common interest' as ultimately determined by the Fair Work Commission, and 'not contrary to the public interest' as ultimately determined by the Fair Work Commission?

Se
nator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:40): Correct.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:40): The next point is that the common interest could be the nature of the enterprise. Can you give an example of two businesses which would be considered having the same nature?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:41): Again, this is ultimately a matter for the discretion of the commission. However, I'd remind you that there are a number of businesses who already make use of this system under your government's legislation. For instance, I believe that in various states and territories Catholic schools have already made use of this system. So that has obviously been a matter that the commission has already deemed to be similar in terms of the nature of the enterprises.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:42): So again we go back to 'ultimately a matter for the discretion of the Fair Work Commission'. If I turn to the revised explanatory memorandum, it says that relevant factors include the relative size and scope of the relevant enterprises. Given you have put this into the explanatory memorandum about the relative size and scope of the relevant enterprises, can you please provide some examples of two businesses who may therefore have the same nature?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:43): Again, I'm not going to speculate on hypotheticals, but while just thinking about this and talking to my colleagues here, I've been reminded that not only do businesses already have the capacity to reach multi-employer agreements under this single-interest bargaining stream under the current law that you administered, but that law, which you administered, left the discretion as to whether businesses should be allowed to be part of a multi-employer bargain to the minister. So you might like to make something of the fact that items are being left to the discretion of the commission, but the system that you presided over gave you, as the minister, the discretion to make these decisions. I think most Australians would feel a lot more comfortable with the Fair Work Commission making those decisions rather than any minister of the day, whatever their political persuasion.

Senator
CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:44): Would any two retail stores be considered as having the same nature?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:44): I'm not going to speculate on hypotheticals.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:44): I'm very much struggling to see how that could possibly be a hypothetical question. Part of the common interest test is clearly articulated in your legislation as being the nature of the enterprise. I am merely asking for further guidance in relation to what is 'the nature of the enterprise'. Would any two retail stores be considered as having the same nature? I am asking for guidance here. The retail sector would like to know.
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:45): I can't add to what I've already said.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:45): Can I ask, then: would it therefore be a matter for the Fair Work Commission to determine?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:45): I can't add to what I've already said.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:45): A butcher and a newsagency are both retail stores. Would they be considered as having the same nature?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:45): I'm not going to speculate on hypotheticals, and I'll be saying exactly the same thing for every such situation you want to put forward.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:45): With all due respect, Minister, this is a significant change to Australia's industrial relations system. Businesses, employees and Australians have had little to no time to properly consider this legislation. That is the right of your government, despite the fact that you were allegedly elected on a basis of integrity and transparency. These are very genuine questions that we are asking in relation to a test that you have put into your bill. In part 21, relating to the single-interest stream, under the section headed 'Common interests'—which is used in various positions throughout the bill—the common interest test lists three conditions for identifying a potential common interest. One is geographical location, and I've accepted now that there is no guidance. I accept that. In every answer you have given—and we can go through the Hansard record tomorrow again—you've said it is left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission. I accept that as an answer. There are no hypotheticals here. These are genuine questions that employers and employees are asking.

Also in the common interest test set out in your bill is 'the nature of the enterprise'. If, when I ask, 'Would any two retail stores be considered as having the same nature?' you are saying to me, 'It's for the discretion of the Fair Work Commission; there is nothing more that I can add to the answer; there is nothing further in the bill that provides any guidance,' well, that's the answer. But you say, 'I won't answer a hypothetical.' How is it possibly a hypothetical when we're asking the question on behalf of retail stores in Australia?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:47): There are any number of hypotheticals that anyone can get up and give, and I'm simply not going to speculate on those hypotheticals, whether it be butcher shops, retail shops, pizza shops—I was going to say video shops, but there are not many of them left these days—burger shops or coffee shops. We could be here all night with any combination of hypotheticals that you want to put forward and what I will keep saying is that these are hypotheticals and I'm not going to speculate on them.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:48): And, yet, at the commencement of your answer you were prepared to put on record that two schools were reasonable. So let's work through this. Two schools are reasonable. Why is it a hypothetical to ask you: would two retail stores be deemed as having the same nature?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:48): It's pretty simple: because the example of the Catholic schools is not a hypothetical; it is a fact that Catholic schools reached a multi-employer agreement under your government and under your legislation—that is not a hypothetical. There were other instances as well in other industries, albeit not that many because the system was so bureaucratic and required ministerial discretion such that it didn't work. So it is a fact that that occurred and, of course, that's different to a hypothetical.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:49): Well, on behalf of the employers across Australia—and I don't have an issue that you have complete contempt for them. I think it's disgusting, but you clearly do have complete contempt for them because they are the ones who are asking—

Senator Watt: Temporary Chair, I raise a point of order, around impugning motives. I ask Senator Cash to withdraw her remarks that I have contempt for anyone. I'm just trying to answer some questions and there are some questions that cannot be answered.
Senator CASH: If Senator Watt is so insulted by the fact that I said he has contempt for business—

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Walsh ): If you're going to withdraw, you should withdraw without condition.

Senator CASH: I will withdraw it, but what I will say is this is very, very disappointing. You are refusing to provide guidance about who could be compelled to bargain together. You are making changes to the system. You are standing here tonight in the committee stage of a bill.
