I said to you at the beginning—I read out to you—the tone in which I would ask the questions, and the importance of questions when it comes to statutory interpretation. To date, despite the farce of the committee process that was undertaken in relation to this bill, despite the alleged consultation that your government keeps saying it has undertaken with businesses across this country, there are hundreds of questions I would put to you, legitimate questions that employers would like answered, before this bill goes through. If you go to your own regulatory impact statement, you can't answer any of these questions. It's at the discretion of the Fair Work Commission. I'd rather you say that it's at the discretion of the Fair Work Commission, because at least then employers would have some idea. But, when you say it is hypothetical, quite frankly you are mocking businesses in Australia, who are the employers in this country. Your own regulatory impact statement says that, if you get into this bargaining process, if you're a small business, you could be $14½ thousand worse off. If you are a medium-sized business it was $75,000, until the $5,000 typo was found out. So they'll need to fork out around $80,000 to get their own advice. What is worse is: you are now saying that we are delving into hypotheticals. So tell me: would two businesses in the mining sector be considered as having the same nature?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:52): I'm not going to comment on hypotheticals. You talked about being disappointed. I know what is really disappointing for the coalition is that wages might get moving again. That's what really disappointing. That's why we see this filibustering, where, even after all this time, even after 10 years of suppressing wages, that's not enough for the coalition. Even after an election where Australians voted for wages to get moving again, that's not enough for the coalition. Even though we're nearly seven months after the election, that's still not enough for the coalition, because the truth is that, for the coalition, it's never the right time for Australian workers to get a pay rise. That's what's disappointing to the coalition. You can ask every hypothetical question you want. You can soak up every minute you want. You can soak up every hour you want. We know you wanted to defer this legislation to next year, and, if we'd gone along with that, you would have wanted to defer it to the year after that and the year after that, because you would rather have two decades of wage suppression than one decade. But we're not going to let that happen. We're determined to change Australia's workplace laws from the decrepit system that you presided over, which delivered 10 years of stagnant wages and low productivity for businesses. It didn't work for anyone. It engendered conflict rather than agreements. It has delivered low wages and low productivity. That is going to change. I'm surprised, frankly, that the coalition didn't hear the message from the Australian people at the election that they wanted something different. Well, we're going to deliver something different, and it's going to benefit not just workers but businesses around this country, and it's long overdue that that happened.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:54): Senator Watt, I've said to you time and time again this evening: political commentary does not aid statutory interpretation. You are in government. This is your legislation, and you are answering the questions—or failing to answer them, in this case. Political commentary does not aid in statutory interpretation. The situation we now find ourselves in is this: given you have given no guidance whatsoever—in fact, you have actually said they are mere hypotheticals, which anyone in Australia knows they are not; they are very genuine questions that are being asked—there is nothing stopping one Fair Work commissioner, because everything is being left 'to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission', considering a butcher and a newsagent to be related businesses with a common interest and another commissioner making a different conclusion.

So I invite you again, on behalf of, in particular, retailers in Australia: is there any further guidance that you can give to them tonight? You are right; this bill is going through. This is the final opportunity that the opposition, the crossbench and the Australian Greens have on behalf of their constituents, the people we represent, and in this case tonight for me it's employers who actually want to do the right thing by their employees. They are saying, 'Can you please get further guidance from the government, so that we have half an idea about what we do?' and the only thing that we have established tonight is, 'It is ultimately a matter for the discretion of the Fair Work Commission.'
I do understand that Senator Pocock does have some questions, and I will cede now to him.

Senator DAVID POCOCK (Australian Capital Territory) (21:56): Minister, can I take you to the definition of 'casuals' and establishing whether they count toward the new threshold of 20 employees in the amendment for exclusion from the single-interest bargaining stream. Would seasonal workers be included in this figure?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:57): Thanks, Senator Pocock, again for your cooperation and negotiations with the government on the amendments that are now being put forward. Ultimately that question comes down to whether the casuals are regular or not. The way the legislation is already drafted is that, essentially, regular casuals would be considered within the 20-employee cap, but irregular casuals—so, people who haven't worked there for a period of time or something like that—would not. That would apply whether we're talking about seasonal workers or other forms of casual employment.
Senator DAVID POCOCK (Australian Capital Territory) (21:58): Thank you, Minister. Would, say, seasonal fruit pickers be regular? What's the line there?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:58): Thanks, Senator Pocock. I'm just going to ask the officials to double-check whether there has ever been any case law on this point to determine whether seasonal workers are considered regular and systematic casuals. I talked about regular, but regular and systematic casuals would be considered employees for the purposes of that cap. I'm very much speculating here. That's really how it works.

Senator DAVID POCOCK (Australian Capital Territory) (21:59): I'll await advice on that. Just on the 20-employee threshold, for someone who owns multiple businesses—for example, bakeries—does the headcount count, say you have three bakeries, across the three bakeries, or is each business on its own?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (21:59): If you're talking about three separate bakeries owned by the same person or entity, the total employee numbers would be combined across the three. If they had a total of 20 or more across the three businesses, then that would be 20 or more. You don't have to have 20 or more in each of the three businesses.
Senator DAVID POCOCK (Australian Capital Territory) (22:00): Minister, can I take you to section 67 of the supplementary EM:

New subsection 216DC(3B) as amended would provide the FWC with discretion to refuse to approve a variation of a single interest employer agreement to cover a new employer and employees, if the FWC is satisfied the variation should not be approved, having regard to whether the employer is bargaining in good faith for a proposed enterprise agreement covering substantially the same group of employees, the parties have a history of effectively bargaining for an enterprise agreement and less than 9 months have passed since the most recent nominal expiry date of such an agreement.
Does the inclusion of consideration of bargaining history respond to specific requests from stakeholders, and if so, who?

Senator
WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:01): The short answer is yes, it results from consultation and feedback from the stakeholders. That in fact came at the Jobs and Skills Summit, where both business groups and unions arrived a consensus that where parties, employer or employee or union, have a history of bargaining effectively, that exemption should apply.

Senator DAVID POCOCK (Australian Capital Territory) (22:02): In terms of the 'reasonably comparable' terminology, can you elaborate on what the government intends where you say at section 53 of the supplementary EM:
This amendment would ensure that the FWC must also be satisfied that the operations and business activities of the employer are also reasonably comparable.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:02): As you would be aware, that term is not defined in the legislation. Again, I guess it would be a common sense test for the commissioner to apply to determine whether a particular business is reasonably comparable to another. I would expect that if they are in a completely different industry, or of completely different scale, it would be difficult to see how the commission could say that those two businesses are reasonably comparable. Again, that's a decision for the commission.

Senator DAVID POCOCK (Australian Capital Territory) (22:03): On the scale, would that be the scale of individual businesses or—I know you're not dealing in hypotheticals, but indulge me in this because I don't know how to explain it—say a Woolworths versus IGA: if all the IGAs are added together, you have the scale. How will that be treated?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:04): To take the specific example of IGAs, I can't really remember what the ownership structure of IGA is, but I think each shop is independently owned. I would think the commission would consider each of those businesses as separate, rather than rolling them together as a conglomeration. Again, it would depend on the terms and conditions of employment of the IGA employees. I actually don't know if they have the same terms and conditions whether they're the IGA in your suburb in Canberra or mine in Brisbane. But, if they are operating quite distinctly with different ownership and different terms and conditions, I would expect that the commission would consider them separate businesses rather than rolling them together as one big group.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:05): Again, if I could just continue in relation to some guidance on the government's common interest test used in various positions throughout part 21. As I've stated, it lists conditions for identifying the potential common interest:
(a) geographical location;
(b) regulatory regime;
(c) the nature of the enterprise … and the terms and conditions of employment in those enterprises.

To date, we've established that it would appear to be left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission to determine those factors. In relation to the terms and conditions of employment in those enterprises, can you confirm what this means in the context of determining whether employers have a common interest, and can you provide some examples?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:06): Just as I am not in a position to elaborate further on the other tests being geographical location or regulatory regime, I'm unable to elaborate further on that point either.

Senator CASH
( Western Australia — Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate ) ( 22:06 ): When you say you're unable to elaborate, is that because there is no further guidance provided in any part of the explanatory memorandum or the bill, and is it, again, going to be left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:06): I've answered these questions repeatedly.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:06): This is the first question I think I've asked in relation to the terms and conditions of employment. I'm going through each of the elements of common interest, so I struggle to understand how you said you've answered these repeatedly when this is my first line of questioning on terms and conditions of employment. Can you therefore confirm that, again, it will be left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission?

S
enator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:07): I'm making the point that for every element we've gone over in detail, for every element of the examples of what may amount to a common interest, I've given the same answer over and over again. I will keep giving the same answer over and over again, so it's in everyone's interests that I refer back to those earlier answers. Again, I make the point that the overarching issue and requirement here is set out in the previous subsection, which is that employers have clearly identifiable common interests and that it's not contrary to the public interest to make the authorisation. That is what is actually required, and the remainder, which Senator Cash wants to go through in detail, are simply examples of what may amount to common interest, and every answer I give will be the same.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:08): Again, this is where it is very unfortunate, because I've said to you I've approached these questions tonight in a very deliberate manner. I've approached them from the perspective of statutory interpretation and the ability for those who are seeking to interpret your legislation, in the very likely event proceedings are commenced, being able to refer to the answers that you have provided to the Australian Senate tonight. I really don't think 'My answers are going be the same for the rest of the questions' is going to help anybody in their efforts when it comes to statutory interpretation. So, can I just confirm then, in relation to the terms and conditions of employment in these enterprises, which is a part of the common interest test or something that can be taken into consideration, you are not going to provide the Senate with any further information in relation to what this means in the context of determining whether employers have a common interest? Can I just confirm that? Then I can move on to my next line of questioning.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:09): What I can confirm is that there are a number of matters within the existing Fair Work Act, that Senator Cash presided over as minister and that the former government presided over as the government for nearly ten years, which leave matters to the discretion of the commission. The approach that the government is taking in this case is no different from what Senator Cash did as minister and the government of which she was a part did themselves.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:10): I beg to differ because I don't believe our government put forward the most egregious changes to the Industrial Relations Act in decades. We were never in this position. You are the government that's bringing forward these changes. So, to be fair again to the employers and employees of this country, who would like to do the right thing by each other, they have to now do the right thing under your legislation, and you are unable to provide them with any further guidance. But I will confirm that, as you said, it will be left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission. That was in relation to the terms and conditions of employment.

I turn to the other part of the common interest test: the regulatory regime. Can you please confirm what this means in the context of applying the common interest test? What does the regulatory regime actually mean?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:11): In this case I can be a bit more specific because I can rely on real-life examples—as opposed to hypothetical examples—where certain groups have reached multi-employer agreements under the existing legislation, which your government presided over. What we're talking about here is regulatory regimes in the sense of childcare regulatory regimes, education regulatory regimes or healthcare regulatory regimes. When those sorts of regulatory regimes apply, that is a matter that could be considered by the commission as demonstrating that particular employers have common interests. Again, this point about discretion is nothing new in Australian workplace law. Under the existing act that your government presided over and that you as minister presided over, Senator Cash, the commission, for example, had discretion on whether to terminate protected industrial action. Your government didn't spell out exactly what the test was, exactly what needed to be satisfied for the commission to determine whether to terminate protected action; it left it to the commission to decide that based on certain factors, which is exactly the approach we're taking here. The better-off-overall test, which has been within the Fair Work Act for some time, may have its detractors and may need improving, and that's what we're doing in this legislation, but no previous government, including yours, including when you were minister, ever spelt out categorically what 'better off overall' meant. That was left to the commission to decide. So, if any employers, employees or unions are listening and concerned by this approach, I imagine they would have had similar concerns about matters being left to the commission to decide in the past.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:13): They weren't confronted with the situation that we're confronted with tonight whereby you are opening up the single-interest stream to multi-employer bargaining and you are potentially compelling who do not want to be part of these agreements. You are saying that they can be compelled if they satisfy a common interest test, but to date the government has not been able to explain the common interest test. You cannot explain what a 'geographic similarity' is, you cannot explain what a 'similar nature' is, you cannot explain what the terms and conditions of employment in those enterprises are and you basically said it will be left to the discretion of the Fair Work Commission. Is that the answer that you have for Australians—it will be left to the Fair Work Commission?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:14): Senator Cash, I'm not sure if you've forgotten the legislation that you presided over as minister, which left any number of matters to the discretion of the commission: whether bargaining periods should be terminated, whether protected action should be terminated, whether a particular agreement was going to leave employees better off overall. They're just the ones that I've sat here and remembered myself over the last three minutes. I haven't even started looking through the act to find every other reference to it. It's a system that you applied. It's a common system. You applied it. It's being applied here now. As I said, what would probably be helpful is if you and your colleagues, as part of a political campaign, didn't run around the country scaring employers about things that won't happen, but that's the path you've chosen.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:15): Again, Minister, political commentary does not aid in statutory interpretation. You keep criticising the former system—the system that was actually set up by the former Rudd and Gillard governments. You are so critical of it, but you now say you're adopting the same approach. I find that a little ironic. Don't you?

In terms of how a business or employer exits the single-interest stream, in the collegiate negotiations that we've been referring to—that they entered into voluntarily and that have now been potentially imposed on them by the Fair Work Commission—if this now moves towards an arrangement that would make the employer's business unviable, because they're no longer negotiating at an enterprise level, they are now potentially being compelled into negotiating with their competitors and they will be ending up with a one-size-fits-all approach. How does the employer, under the act, actually exit the single-interest stream?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:16): Thanks, Senator Cash. This matter is dealt with by one of the new amendments. I think clause 53 refers to that. It refers to schedule 1, item 637 on page 11 of the new amendments. Essentially, there are two ways for an employer to exit a single-interest bargain while it is in force. They both require application to the commission.
Opposition senators interjecting—

Senator WATT: Sorry, exiting the authorisation, which is the terminology for being part of a—you get authorisation from the commission to be part of a single-interest bargain. The two ways, which both require application to the commission, are (1) demonstrating to the commission that the employer's circumstances have changed and (2) a majority vote of the employees supports exiting that agreement or that authorisation.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:18): They only have to show one of those reasons?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:18): Yes, they are the circumstances. The point about having a majority vote of employees, that's only required for businesses with 50 or fewer employees—it's fewer than 50. It's available as an option for businesses with fewer than 50 employees. It will end up being subsection 251(2A), which deals with the circumstances that allow the Fair Work Commission to vary an authorisation.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:18): So, this is an amendment that the government is bringing in. It provides an avenue for a business or an employer to exit the single-interest stream. For example, in the event that the one-size-fits-all agreement that they now have to work under actually means the employer's business becomes unviable, resulting in probable business destruction and associated job loss, there is a mechanism in the bill for them to exit the single-interest stream. They make an application to the commission. They either have a majority vote of the employees, or they must prove they have had a change in circumstances. How will they prove a change in circumstances? What does this mean?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:20): It is exactly the same test in as in the current act, being the act you administered as minister.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:20): Again, political commentary does not assist with statutory interpretation. These are very deliberate questions that are being asked. Employers have been unable to work this out. They've just seen the amendment. Could you take me through what is a change in circumstances? They've been compelled into a multi-employer agreement. The multi-employer agreement has resulted in their business now becoming unviable. They wish to exit. They can apply to the commission with a majority vote or they can prove they have had a change in circumstances. Can you take us through how they will prove this?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:21): I don't think you need me to explain that because it's in the act you administered as the minister. It is exactly the same test. Having been, like you, an industrial lawyer—although I suspect probably on different sides of matters—I have certainly had a lot of experience of unions and employees being willing to renegotiate terms and conditions of their employment when faced with serious viability concerns, so I have every confidence that, just as unions and employees have been able to approach these issues maturely with employers in the past, they will continue to do so under the new system as well.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:21): With all due respect, I may have been an industrial lawyer; you may have been an industrial lawyer. The problem with that is, though, that is not the small business or medium business or large business tonight seeking guidance from this part of the debate being merely referred to a particular section of the act, because they don't have the time to now go and find a copy of the Fair Work Act, flip through to 'change in circumstances' and work out what it means. So with all due respect, I would like an answer to: If an employer must prove they've had a change in circumstances, how will they prove it?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:22): They will prove it in exactly the same way they had to prove it under the legislation that you presided over as minister. Remember, single-interest bargaining, multi-employer bargaining have been available under the legislation that exists now, that you presided over as the minister. Section 251 of the current act spells out how an employer can seek to vary a single-interest employer authorisation by removing the employer's name. Let me read you the current section 251, subsection 2—your legislation; you were the minister.

(2) If an application is made under subsection (1), the FWC must vary the authorisation to remove the employer's name if the FWC is satisfied that, because of a change in the employer's circumstances, it is no longer appropriate for the employer to be specified in the authorisation.

So if it's not okay for our government to not provide further detail on that then I guess my question to you, Senator Cash is: Why didn't you fix it when you were the minister and had exactly the same wording in your legislation?

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:24): This is a fundamental change to Australia's industrial relations laws. We're talking about entering into multi-employer agreements that you have been compelled to enter into. When you consider the process of exiting can you confirm if this will present additional costs to businesses?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:24): I'm advised that there is no fee to apply for this kind of a variation, in the same way that there was no fee to apply for a variation to the very multi-employer bargaining that was available through your legislation but that didn't work. And I'm glad you reminded me of the cost issues, Senator Cash, because that's of course been one of the other scare campaigns you've been out there running, and you did it again tonight—about the thousands of dollars that small businesses were going to have to pay to be part of multi-employer bargaining. Wrong! The whole point of multi-employer bargaining is that it gives various employer groups, chambers of commerce and other associations the opportunity to design agreements that would work across a range of different employers.

I would hazard a guess that most small businesses or medium-size businesses that want to take part in multi-employer bargaining would choose to take advantage of an agreement that has already been designed for them by an employer group, rather than deciding to go and engage a consultant at their cost to help them through the process. If they choose to go and engage a consultant to help them through the process and incur the thousands of dollars that that involves, then that's a matter for them. But no-one's forcing them to do that. No-one's forcing them or compelling them to do anything. We're offering a different version of the same multi-employer bargaining that you saw fit to preside over, but apparently it's not okay when a Labor government tries to do it.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:26): We are not 'forcing' or 'compelling' them to do anything. Under this legislation, then, if an employer does not want to enter into a multi-employer agreement, what is the pathway for joining them?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:26): As I've said over the course of the night, for any employer to become part of a multi-employer agreement they have to meet various tests. Businesses that don't meet those tests won't be part of a multi-employer agreement. I know it doesn't fit the narrative. I know it doesn't help with the scare campaigns. But that's how the system works.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:27): Perhaps I could now go to the issue of costs and the letter between the Office of Best Practice Regulation and the department dated 24 October 2022, in which the Office of Best Practice Regulation provides its assessment of the government's regulatory impact statement on bargaining changes. The Office of Best Practice Regulation's assessment was that the regulatory impact statement is 'adequate and therefore sufficient to inform decision'. However, the letter states that to have been assessed as good practice under the guide the regulatory impact statement would have benefited from further analysis of the potential impacts on productivity, real wages and other distributional impact, in particular on gender, and that statements or evidence that the regulatory costs and their assumptions had been tested with stakeholders or otherwise an acknowledgement of why this has not been undertaken.

My question therefore is: in light of the Office of Best Practice's statement, the good practice would have been for the department to have undertaken analysis on the potential impacts of bargaining changes on real wages. Why did this not happen?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:28): I'm advised that all the requirements of the Office of Best Practice Regulation—or whatever its exact name is; I think that's what it's called—were met. So, we believe we've met all those requirements.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:29): Again, let me just put to you what the Office of Best Practice Regulation said. It said that its assessment of the RIS, the regulatory impact statement, is adequate and therefore sufficient to inform decision. However, the letter states:
To have been assessed as good practice under the Guide, the RIS would have benefited from:
• further analysis of the potential impacts on productivity, real wages and other distributional impacts, in particular on gender …
• statements or evidence that the regulatory costs and their assumptions had been tested with stakeholders, or otherwise an acknowledgement why this had not been undertaken.
In relation to that statement by the Office of Best Practice Regulation, what action did the government take?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:30): Again, Senator Cash, I think you've answered your own question by referring to what was contained in the first part of that letter, which were words to the effect that the work that was done was adequate. It was what was needed. I know that a lot of these questions go to gender impacts of the bill. I've already made the point that this bill is going to be doing an enormous amount to rectify and close the gender pay gap that exists in Australia and that has been happening for a very long time. I know your government used to crow about closing the gender pay gap, but you always left out the bit that the reason that happened was that male wages were falling. So to close the gender pay gap in the Liberal-National world was to see wages decline for one part of the community. What we actually want to see is the gender pay gap closing with both gender's pay going up; that's the way to close the gender pay gap.

As I say, this bill does an enormous amount to address gender inequality in industrial relations in Australia by including gender equality as an overarching object of the Fair Work Act; by implementing the government's election commitment to establish expert panels for pay equity; and by including the care and community sector in the Fair Work Commission, backed by a dedicated research unit. There are the issues around banning pay secrecy clauses and allowing staff to talk about their pay if they want to, which is particularly important for women; there is stamping out workplace sexual harassment; and there is extending eligibility for flexible work requests to cover cases where the employee is pregnant. Any reasonable observer would see that this bill is going to do more for gender equality in the workplace than we have seen in this country for a very, very long time. It's a shame that the former government didn't do anything about these issues for the 10 years that it was in power.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:32): Again, political commentary is of no assistance in statutory interpretation. The issue I have with the answer that you just gave is that you have stated that the regulatory impact statement says it is adequate. You've accepted that and therefore you've discharged your obligations. You then went on about a number of impacts in relation to gender. The issue I have is this, though. What the regulatory impact statement says is that the RIS would have benefited from further analysis of the potential impact, in particular on gender. Given that statement, and given your commitment in this bill to the improvements in gender equity, when the minister received this and it said 'further analysis of the potential impacts on productivity, real wages and other distributional impacts, in particular on gender', what action was taken?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:33): Again, many aspects of this bill—many core aspects of this bill—are designed explicitly to address and repair the gender pay gap and to improve the position of women in the workplace in a number of different ways. I respect that the Office of Best Practice Regulation is entitled to its view. Its view was also that the work that we had done was adequate—I think was the word it used—to meet its requirements. I can also say that, over the consultation and preparation of this bill, there has been extensive consultation with recognised academics, women's organisations and a number of—
Senator Cash: Unions?

Senator
WATT: Yes, unions—employer groups. Unions do have a concern about women's place in the workplace and improving their position.
Senator Cash interjecting—

Senator WATT: Well, you raised unions, so I'm just trying to give you feedback. Unions do have a long history of campaigning for women's rights in the workplace. That's one of the reasons I'm a union member. So we did consult with a number of different academics, unions, employer groups, women's organisations and civil society groups that have an interest in these issues, and we've taken on board their feedback, and that's why this bill does more to improve the position of women in the workplace than we've seen for a very long time.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:35): Again, the answer actually was not in relation to my question. That was some commentary. The Office of Best Practice Regulation's assessment—and we will get onto the levels; 'adequate' is not as good as you're making it sound, and we'll explore that shortly—said that the RIS would have benefited from further analysis of the potential impacts on productivity, real wages and other distributional impact, in particular on gender. What I'm asking is: when you read that, what did you do? If the answer's 'nothing', that's fine.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:36): I can't really add to what I've already said, other than to remind you that this bill is the result of lengthy and detailed conversations and consultation with a large number of academics, women's organisations, other groups, employers and unions, who had some very valuable ideas about how we could fix the gender pay gap, and I'm really pleased that this bill picks it up.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Reynolds ): Senator Pocock, I understand Senator Cash has one more question in the line, and then I'll come straight to you.

Senator
CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:36): I have several more questions, but I'll ask one more question, and then I will obviously, absolutely. Can I just confirm: what was the gender pay gap when the coalition came to office in May 2013, and what was the gender pay gap when you assumed office in May of this year?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:37): I'm happy to get you those figures, and I'm also happy to get you the proof that any reduction in the gender pay gap that may have occurred over your time in office was because male wages in real terms or relative terms fell. So I'm not really sure that I'd be particularly proud of any statistics that demonstrated that the relative pay of either gender fell, but I'm very happy to provide those figures to you.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (22:37): I have a question pursuing the line of questioning from Senator Cash. We've heard this evening how the character of the Fair Work Commission is going to be very important to the way in which the promise of this bill unfolds and is realised. What kind of expertise in relation to gender, equal remuneration, job security and so on is going to be essential in the commission to realise the promise of the bill and, in particular, the expertise in the two new panels established, one on care and community and one on gender equality?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:38): Thanks, Senator Pocock. I again recognise your many years of working and campaigning on these issues. You're dead right: it is important. An understanding and appreciation of gender issues and gender inequality is a really important characteristic, I think and the government thinks, of members of the commission. You're probably aware that one of the things that we're proposing to do here is to establish two particular panels, one concerning pay equity and one concerning, I think, the care and community sector. We would certainly expect that the commissioners who are involved in those panels would have a particular understanding of these issues. So I do think that it improves decision-making on gender inequality issues if the people making these decisions—the commissioners—have a deep understanding of these issues. That's certainly the path we want to go down.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (22:39): Have you given any consideration to evaluation of the expertise of the commission and its ability to enact the new objects of the act and so on, to make sure that it is doing what we want it to do if the bill is passed with those new objects?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:40): As you may be aware, in the budget this year the government announced $20 million to establish those two panels that I was referring to—the Pay Equity Expert Panel and the Care and Community Sector Expert Panel—with a dedicated research unit. I've been reminded that the relevant skills and experience are a requirement of appointees to the panels, so I would fully expect that the people who will be involved in these panels will have those sorts of skills and backgrounds.

Senator BARBARA POCOCK (South Australia) (22:40): There was some discussion in the committee that took evidence in relation to the bill about the nature of appointments to those panels, and to the commission more broadly, in relation to part-time and full-time appointments. Do you anticipate part-time appointments that can draw on the academic expertise and the general industry and union expertise that's out there on these issues?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:41): Yes. It would be somewhat ironic if we weren't open to part-time membership of these sorts of panels that are considering gender inequality issues. What I'm advised is that expert panel members can be appointed on a full-time basis but also can be appointed on a part-time basis, for a five-year term. The part-time nature of this appointment reflects the short-term nature of the tasks these experts are appointed to perform, for example, the annual wage review. The president will also have the power to appoint full-time members to panels based on their expertise, and that will give the commission some flexibility with its resourcing.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:42): If we could continue on the regulatory impact statement and the letter between the Office of Best Practice Regulation and the department dated 23 October 2022. In terms of the Office of Best Practice Regulation assessment tiers, I understand that there's actually four. You've said that you are happy with 'adequate'. Can I confirm that?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:42): I didn't express a level of happiness or unhappiness. What I said was that the letter that you read from stated that the office considered that the work that we did was adequate.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:43): 'Adequate for decision-making'—there is actually a big difference. In terms of the Office of Best Practice Regulation assessment tiers, there are actually, I understand, four—insufficient, adequate, good practice and exemplary practice. Let's go through them again. Insufficient—bad, bad. Adequate—mmm. Good practice—we're starting to get there. And then there's exemplary practice. Page 55 of the Australian Guide to Regulatory Impact Analysis describes 'adequate' as follows:

Adequate means the RIS is sufficient for a decision, but contains a number of shortcomings in its analysis and/or the policy development process used to underpin the analysis, such as not conducting a reasonable level of consultation.

I go back to the Office of Best Practice's assessment. It says the regulatory impact statement would have benefited from 'statements or evidence that the regulatory costs'—and we'll pursue them—'and their assumptions had been tested with stakeholders, or otherwise an acknowledgment why this was not undertaken'. What action did the government take in that regard? Given, in particular, the fact that the RIS is merely assessed as adequate, it means it has a number of shortcomings in its analysis and/or the policy development process used to underpin the analysis, such as not conducting a reasonable level of consultation. So, when presented with statements or evidence that the regulatory costs and their assumptions had been tested with stakeholders or, otherwise, an acknowledgment of why this had not been undertaken, what action did the minister take?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:45): Again, I thank you, Senator Cash, for pointing out that the guidance note or whatever it was that you were quoting from says that, when the work is deemed to be adequate, that is, I think your words were, 'sufficient on which to base a decision'. So it sounds to me as though the work that was done was deemed to be sufficient to make a decision, and that's what we've done. I think it would probably be interesting to find out whether regulation and legislation that occurred while you, Senator Cash, were a minister ever hit the 'adequate' note as well. I suspect that it has probably been the case in most ministers' careers that sometimes it's deemed to be a higher level or a lower level, and I suspect we could find examples where that happened when you were the minister as well. But, given that this point ultimately relates to gender inequality, I've already given references to the extensive work that occurred to ensure that the act delivered on gender equality in the workplace and I've already run through the numerous ways in which the bill does that.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:46): It also related to the impacts on productivity and real wages. Are you therefore satisfied, in light of the Office of Best Practice Regulation's assessment, that an appropriate level of consultation has been undertaken for the bargaining changes?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:46): Yes, I am. As you have said, the office found that the work that was undertaken was adequate and that it was sufficient to base a decision on. We've made a decision and we're now getting on with legislating so that we can get wages moving again.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:47): Does the department usually aim only for an adequate assessment?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:47): I don't know what the department's practice is, but I'm sure that it always aspires to the highest level. I'm sure it always aspired to the highest level when you were the minister, Senator Cash, and I'm sure that sometimes it got there and sometimes it got to adequate.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:47): That's a pretty stunning answer, I have to say, but not in a good way. Given that we all accept 'adequate', 'good enough to inform a decision', 'too bad, so sad' about what the Office of Best Practice Regulation actually said, why did the government not take any further action when it was advised by the Office of Best Practice Regulation that the regulatory impact statement could be improved? You actually have had an opportunity to provide an updated explanatory memorandum as well. Is there a reason that this was not addressed?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:48): It would be false to suggest, as I think you're suggesting, that consultation did not continue after that letter was received. There has been extensive consultation both prior to and after the receipt of that letter. But, again, we make no apologies for bringing this legislation to the chamber to get it passed before Christmas, because Australians have been waiting for 10 years to have an IR system which delivers fair pay rises so that people can keep up with the cost of living. I know that your government had a different policy. I know that your government's policy was to keep wages suppressed and to keep productivity low. We don't want that. We don't want workers or businesses to have to wait a day longer than is necessary to get the system working so that we get wages moving and we get productivity moving, which will benefit the Australian economy overall.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:49): Minister Watt, this bill will pass the Senate—probably tomorrow. I have no issues with that. But tonight and tomorrow is our opportunity to ask detailed questions in relation to the impact of the legislation and the absolute confusion out there in relation to the changes. To date, you have been making, quite frankly, a mockery of the entire process.

I note the Office of Best Practice Regulation has criticised the department for not providing evidence that the regulatory costs and their assumptions have been tested with stakeholders. If you go to page 50 of the regulatory impact statement, it says 'the impact on employers of option 2, improving access to single and multi-employer agreements'. This section refers to a number of assumptions—and we will go through the assumptions—that underpin the department's estimate that the cost of multi-employer bargaining changes—and I want to pursue an answer you gave previously, when I said the cost to small business was around $14,500 and you yelled out 'not true'; I would like to pursue why you say that's not true.

This section refers to a number of assumptions that underpin the department's estimate of what the cost of multi-employer bargaining changes per business would be. If you go to page 53 of the regulatory impact statement, it sets them out. It says this: 'Therefore, the total cost per business using these estimates are cost of bargaining per business plus cost of external consultants per business. Small business, $14,638. Medium business, $75,148'—we now know that's not true; there was a $5,000 typo which actually increased, not decreased, the cost of business—and the cost of a large business is $94,311. So, when I said the cost of bargaining per business plus cost as outlined in your RIS was $14,638 for a small business, why is that untrue?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:51): Thanks, Senator Cash. The reason I was saying you were wrong earlier and I'm saying you're wrong now is that you and your colleagues have repeatedly cited those figures as being so-called evidence that any business that wants to take part in the type of bargaining that's been put forward here will incur those costs. That is not true. That assumes that the relevant business decides to go and get its own consultants, its own lawyers, its own this, its own that, when that is not the only option they have available to them. As I said earlier in the debate, what I would expect would happen is we would see some of the employer groups, whether they be industry based or across industry, develop agreements as a service to their members that their members, the individual businesses, may choose to then join up to. If businesses decided to do that, they wouldn't need to incur the cost of external consultants. All it would cost them is their usual membership fee for that association. Those employer groups already provide an extensive range of industrial relations services to their members. This would become another one that they could offer. So to claim, as you and your colleagues have now for a number of weeks, that any business that wants to participate in this is going to be up for tens of thousands of dollars is completely untrue, and you know that. But you continue to say it because it feeds your scare campaigns and your narrative. It's just not true.

In addition, what you've failed to point out again is the following words that are in the regulatory impact statement, which are: 'The significant benefits of being covered by an enterprise agreement and the cost that may be associated with remaining covered by a modern award outweigh the additional cost for businesses to engage with the new multi-enterprise bargaining streams.' If you're going to be citing things from the regulatory impact statement, (a) you might owe it to people to be complete and (b) you might owe it to people to not misrepresent what it's saying. People do not have to choose this option if they don't want to.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:54): You've clearly never met a small business, if that's your answer. Let's now talk about some further assumptions, seeing as you're all over business and all over what businesses are going to do. The first is: how many small businesses in Australia are a member of an association?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:54): The number would be extremely large. I base that on the repeated comments from employer groups that they speak for small businesses in this country. If the likes of ACCI, COSBOA, AiG and all the other employer groups say they represent small businesses or medium-size businesses in this country, then they must represent a very large number, and they must be very capable of developing agreements that their members could then sign up to. Frankly, I think that part of their responsibility to their members is to provide them with that industrial relations assistance so that they can have that assistance from their member body.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:55): Before we finish tonight, there is another assumption I'd like to pursue with you. I note the government's assumption that on average 15.2 employers—I'd love you to explain the 0.2 to me, because I'm a little confused about the 0.2—will bargain together under the one multi-employer agreement. Where did the 15.2 come from, and what does the 0.2 represent?
Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:56): Sorry, which document are you quoting from, Senator Cash?
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:56): Your regulation impact statement that was assessed as adequate.

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:56): I'm getting some further advice on this, but what I understand at the moment is that it's based on the average number of businesses that joined multi-enterprise agreements under the system that you presided over as minister.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:57): The government's assumption is that on average 15.2 employers will bargain together under one multi-employer agreement and that they will pool their money and hire one or two consultants—throw it in the air; 'one or two', 'three or four', doesn't matter, though costs do get more expensive the higher we go—to represent them during negotiations. I personally find it fascinating, colleagues, that competitors who are forced to bargain are going to say, 'We'll just give you all our information, and then you can negotiate between the 15.2 employers and come up with a one-size-fits-all agreement.' But my question to you is this: did the government put this proposition to employers?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:58): Again, I'll get some further advice on this, but it's sounding to me as if the department based these figures and these assumptions on the experience of what occurred under the system that you presided over. If that's the system that happened when you were in government, were you critical of that as well, or is it only when it's a Labor government that seeks to do this?
Senator Cash interjecting—

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Reynolds ): Order! Senator Cash, wait for the call.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (22:58): That wasn't the question that I asked. The question I asked was: did the government put this proposition to employers? We aren't talking about the regime that was put together by former prime ministers Rudd and Gillard. We aren't talking about the regime that exists today. We are talking about the regime that will exist when this legislation passes. You've made assumptions that on average 15.2 employers will bargain together under the one multi-employer agreement and that they will pool their money. You've got to remember that in this scenario the 15.2 could have been compelled to bargain. That is not something that currently occurs. You've assumed that they will only hire one or two consultants—so the 15 of them might be in competition, but each one of them is going to say, 'We'll only hire one or two consultants'—to represent them during the negotiations. Did the government put this proposition to employers?

Senator WATT (Queensland—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and Minister for Emergency Management) (22:59): As I say, if it is the case—and I'll confirm this—that this is largely based on experience to date, then what we're dealing with there are facts rather than hypotheticals, and they are facts that arose under the system that you presided over as the minister. That would seem to me to be a pretty good place to base assumptions. I guess we'll resume in the morning.

The TEMPO
RARY CHAIR ( Senator Reynolds ): That's a very good segue. It being 11 pm, I shall now report to the Senate.
Progress reported.
